text:
Welcome
Welcome to our first Git & Github course!

Hi üëã ‚ÄÇMy name is Serena ‚Äî Data Scientist‚ÄÇEpidemiology / Neuroscience / Psychology
Disaclaimer time: I am not an expertI use these tools daily and find them, honestly, really useful


Today, I‚Äôll walk with you as you:

Find out some (very cool) ways to integrate Git and GitHub into your daily work
Install and congifure Git and get it working smoothly with GitHub ‚ÄÇin the shell & in R/RStudio
Practice a few key workflows to solve common problems

About you
No previous experience required, beside a general familiarity with data analysis.
You will get the most out of this workshop if you are an R user.

Hungry for more?

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Roadtrip agenda

Big-picture motivation (and a pinch of ranting)

Why would a researcher use a version control system (e.g., Git)?
What‚Äôs the point of hosting your work online (e.g., on GitHub)?



Useful Git/GitHub concepts I keep in my purse
Getting started (the right way): configuration climbing
Early Git wins: some basic workflows for everyday life



The rest of the game: some lesser-known fun things you can do with Github

e.g.¬†Github Pages, Search, and Actions

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Is it going to hurt?
Yes.

Before you can get started, you have to: install Git, get local Git talking to GitHub, and make sure RStudio can talk to local Git (and, therefore, GitHub).
This is one-time or ‚Äúonce-per-computer‚Äù pain & we will do it together


Beginner‚Äìintermediate use requires(small) changes to your normal, daily workflow: e.g.¬†dedicate a directory to each project, make it a git repository, periodically make commits and push them to Github.
It feels weird at first but quickly becomes second nature & we will do it together


Advanced GitHub use, e.g.¬†to work with other people or coordinate your own work from multiple computers? Knock-knock ‚Äî Who‚Äôs there? ‚Äî merge conflicts.
This is not one-time pain but the best remedy is prevention, which we do today

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Why bother with all this?
I can think of two main reasons:

The noble reasons
Science is in bad shape people.
Replicability and traceability of scientific claims is horrifyingly insufficient, across fields.
You analysis is the scientific product, the paper is just advertisement.
And analyses should (in principle)be directly accessible to others,or at least carefullydocumented‚Ä¶




The selfish reasons
Research produces many files: data files, figures, tables, docs, slides, and (yes) code‚Ä¶
Most of these files evolve over the course of a project and often need to be shared with others.
Without explicit and structured management, project organization can easily descend into chaos, and taking your mental wellbeing with it (ask me how I know‚Ä¶)

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: The ‚Äúpoor man‚Äôs version‚Äù of version control
text: The ‚Äúpoor man‚Äôs version‚Äù of version control

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
What is Git?

Git is a version control system.
It manages the evolution of a set of files (a repository or repo) in a sane, highly structured way.

Git‚Äôs original purpose was to help groups of developers work collaboratively on big software projects.
It is like a ‚ÄúTrackChanges‚Äù feature from Microsoft Word, but more rigorous, powerful, and scaled up to multiple files.


It enables the distribution of any file across different people, computers, and across time.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Now the bad news
Git was not built for you.
You will undoubtedly notice this, so it‚Äôs best to know in advance.


Git‚Äôs model of file management can feel uncomfortably rigid, especially for beginners.



Happily, there are many helpful tools that mediate your interactions with Git.
   



‚ÄúI like offending people because I think people who get offended, should be offended.‚Äù 
Linus Torvalds

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
What is GitHub?
GitHub complements Git by providing a polished user interface and distribution mechanism for Git repositories.


Git = software you use locally to record changes to a set of files.
GitHub = hosting service that provides a Git-aware home for such projects on the internet.



GitHub is like DropBox or Google Drive, but much, much better.
It allows others to browse project files, explore their history, sync up with the current version, and even propose or make changes.



Many operations can be done entirely in the browser, including editing or adding files.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Some nice examples from bio-research
A diverse range of efforts (from individual, to labs, to global collaborations) have chosen GitHub as productive place to share code and ideas

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: Benefits of using hosted version control
text:
Benefits of using hosted version control
In a nutshel: doing your work becomes tightly integrated with organizing, recording, and disseminating it. It‚Äôs not a separate, burdensome task you are tempted to neglect.

Tell the story of your project.Make analytical decisions traceable by documenting them as you go.
Back up your work!
Travel back in time and experiment with changes.When you are new with coding (or, frankly, even when you are not), it is common to mess things up. Sometimes the easiest fix is to get a fresh copy from GitHub and move on with your life.
Make it visible: little extra effort required to create a web presence for a project.The highly functional web interface makes it a pleasure to browse through your own work.You can navigate and search through multiple projects and files and across time.
Collaboration and knowledge sharing is much easier and more structured (with collegues as well as remote contributors).GitHub also makes a fantastic course management system for teachers.
Git is WIDELY used outside these walls (required for most job positions).By using common mechanics across work modes (research, teaching, analysis), you achieve basic competence quickly and avoid the demoralizing forget-relearn cycle

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Git basics

Let‚Äôs talk a bit more about Git.
In this section we will:

introduce the most important basic ideas
define some Git vocabulary
link each concept to research-related tasks or projects


Keep in mind that actual usage is the most effective way to build up a good mental model for Git, so don‚Äôt worry if some concept don‚Äôt feel so clear just yet
Once again, there many excellent external Resources at the end of the presenation.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Repositories ( repos ) and roles
Recall: Git manages the evolution of a set of files
Such set of files (or directory) is called a repository (repo for friends).
A repository can be public or private.

Roles
The owner of a repo can grant permission to others (collaborators): e.g.¬†read (only relevant for private repos), write (push) and admin access.
A repo can be owned by a person or by an Organization.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Commits
A commit is a snapshot of one or more files inside a repository.
Instead of saving a copy of a file, versioning it chaging it‚Äôs name (e.g.¬†‚Äú[‚Ä¶] _v2‚Äù or ‚Äú[‚Ä¶] _SD‚Äù), you create a commit.





On the surface nothing changes, but the history of that file is secretly saved, including metadata (e.g.¬†author, date, message)
You can add information about the changes you made in a commit message

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Staging
Actually, Git commits happen in two distinct steps (though they are often used together).

Stage (via git add): tell Git which changes from your repo you intend to include in the next commit.
Commit (via git commit): take what is in the staging area and create a new commit object in the repo‚Äôs history, with its message and unique ID.








Why is this useful?


Recall: a commit is a snapshot of one or more files
Staging lets you split your work into logical commits, even if you edited many files or made mixed changes in the same file.
For example, you can stage only the lines related to a bugfix and commit them separately from formatting changes, improving history readability and making review and rollback easier.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Time travel: hashs and tags
Commits help you tell the story of your project (to yourself and to other people).
But it does not end there‚Ä¶ Git also lets you time travel through your project.
Getting the files from a commit in the past is known as doing a check out






Recall: each commit has a unique ID called a hash.
You can tell Git what commit I want to check out using (part of) the commit hash.
My other commits still exist, but when I look in my repo, it‚Äôs as if they never happened.

You can also give certain commits a special name (a tag) that you can then use to refer to them during time travel e.g.¬†people often use tags for software versions.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Parallel universes: branches
So far, everything has been very linear and ordered. The thing is‚Ä¶ this isn‚Äôt really how projects work.
Sometimes you want to try something out, make experiments.
The way you do this in Git is with branches

A branch is a moveable label attached to a commit.





The default branch name in Git is main (not master!)
It‚Äôs common for the main branch to hold a stable version of the code or files, while other branches contain work in progress.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Quantum collapse: merging
Branches are easy to throw away if you decide you don‚Äôt like your changes.
But if you are happy with some work, you typically want to combine it back into the main branch.

To get changes from one branch into another, you merge them.





This last commit is a combination of all of the commits from both branches.
* Different collaborators can work on different branches independently!

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Remote (vs.¬†local) repositories
Everyone knows that you should back up your work regularly, ideally somewhere geographically distinct from your computer.
In Git this place is called a remote. A very popular place to put your remotes is Github.

Having a remote copy of your repos has several advantages:

It‚Äôs safer: you won‚Äôt loose your work
Can be accessed from different places: e.g.¬†a server, your work laptop, your personal laptop‚Ä¶
Can have shared access with other people (if you want it to)

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: Working with (your) remotes: cloning, pushing and pulling
text:
Working with (your) remotes: cloning, pushing and pulling



To get some work from a remote on your local computer (for the first time) you clone it.








To send new updates to the remote you push





To get new updates (commits) from the remote you pull

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: Working with someone else‚Äôs repo: forking and pull requests
text:
Working with someone else‚Äôs repo: forking and pull requests
Cloning is a client-side Git operation: it creates a local copy of a remote repo.

When you are not a collaborator on the original repo (e.g., open-source contributions), you usually want your own independent remote to work with.



Forking creates a new remote copy of someone else‚Äôs repo (the upstream repo), under your user.
To propose changes back to the original, you‚Äôll use a pull request (PR) instead of pushing directly.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
GitHub‚Äôs got Issues
Issues are essentially a list of things: bugs, feature requests, to-dos, whatever
Issues are handy for project management becasue they can be assigned to people (e.g., to-dos) and tagged (e.g.¬†bug or progress-report).
They are tightly integrated with:

email, allowing you to copy/embed important conversations in the associated repo
commits allowing you to record that, e.g.¬†‚Äúthe changes in this commit solve the problem discussed in that issue.‚Äù








Tip


As a new GitHub user, one of the most productive things you can do is to use GitHub issues to provide a clear bug report or feature request for a package you use.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Questions?

No? Let‚Äôs play a game

and then‚Ä¶ break time

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Bonus: fun fact
The GitHub mascot is named Octocat, a merge between an octopuss and cat.
Do you know the story behind this logo creation?

The idea came from the ‚Äúoctopus merge‚Äù ‚Äì the practice of combining three or more branches of development.
The logo was created by Simon Oxley (who doesn‚Äôt remember creating it, apparently). Initially, Simon thought of calling his creation ‚ÄúOctopuss‚Äù (combination of octopus and pussycat) to represent how complex code combines can create peculiar things.


In the end, GitHub decided to go with Octocat (for obvious reasons).

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Half the battle
Getting all the necessary software installed, configured, and playing nicely together is honestly half the battle when first adopting Git.

You will find far more resources for how to use Git than for installation and configuration.


Why? The experts ‚Ä¶

Have been doing this for years. It‚Äôs just not hard for them anymore.
Probably use some flavor of Unix & they may secretly (or not so secretly) take pride in neither using nor knowing anything about Windows.
In their defense, it‚Äôs hard to write installation instructions.Failures can be specific to an individual OS or even individual computer‚Ä¶



But‚Ä¶ we are in this together! So let‚Äôs set you up (the right way)

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: Is R and RStudio up to date?
text:
Is R and RStudio up to date?
This is a great time to make sure your R installation is current.
# Check your current R version 
R.version.string

# ... and (optionally) update your R packages
update.packages(ask = FALSE, checkBuilt = TRUE)







Is my R version ‚Äúold‚Äù?


R had a major version change in April 2020, with the release of 4.0.0. It is a good idea to be on the current major version (meaning 4.something)
Each major version is followed by several years of smaller (minor and patch) releases. You can be more relaxed about upgrading minor versions, but you still want to stay reasonably current. My advise: never fall more than 1 minor version behind.
You don‚Äôt want to adopt new things on day one. But at some point, running old versions of software adds unnecessary difficulty. So get current, people.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
The shell
The shell is a program on your computer whose job is to run other programs.
Also known as: terminal, command line, console or bash
In research departments, you usually see this program when working on a server (that does not have a GUI client).

Even if you do most of your Git operations via a client (e.g., RStudio or GitHub), you will sometimes need tp work in the shell.


As you get more comfortable with Git, you might even prefer to do more and more via the shell.
So, let‚Äôs get acquainted‚Ä¶

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Opening the shell

From‚ÄÇRStudioOn macOSWindows is special‚Ä¶ not in a good way


It is often handy to launch a shell from RStudio, hear me out.
Why? Because RStudio makes an effort to put you in a sane working directory(the current project).
To launch a shell within RStudio: Tools > Terminal


The shell is often called the ‚Äúterminal‚Äù.
One way to launch it is via Spotlight Search: hit Command‚åò+Space and start typing ‚Äúterminal‚Äù.



There are many possible shells you can end up in.
Unless you know better, use the Git Bash shell. This is the shell that ships with Git for Windows (so, you will have it on your system once you install Git).

RStudio should automatically detect the presence of Git Bash. You can inspect and influence this via Tools > Global Options > Terminal.
To access Git Bash outside of RStudio: open the the Windows menu, click on the ‚ÄúGit‚Äù folder and select ‚ÄúGit Bash‚Äù.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Is Git installed?
Go to the shell and type:
which git
This should give you the path to your Git executable.
Let‚Äôs also check which version you are using:
git --version
If you see something like git: command not found you (likely) don‚Äôt have Git intalled.
Let‚Äôs fix that.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Install Git (if you haven‚Äôt)
You need Git, so let‚Äôs install it.

WindowsmacOSLinux


Install Git for Windows, also known as msysgit or ‚ÄúGit Bash‚Äù, to get Git in addition to some other useful tools, such as the Bash shell.

NOTE: When asked about ‚ÄúAdjusting your PATH environment‚Äù, make sure to select ‚ÄúGit from the command line and also from 3rd-party software‚Äù. Otherwise, accept the defaults.

You should now have a Git executable at: C:/Program Files/Git/bin/git.exe.


Install the Xcode command line tools (not all of Xcode), which includes Git.
In the terminal type:
xcode-select --install


Install Git via your distro‚Äôs package manager.
Ubuntu or Debian:
sudo apt-get install git
Fedora or RedHat:
sudo yum install git

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Introduce yourself to Git

In the shellIn‚ÄÇR


Type:
git config --global user.name "Serena Defina"
git config --global user.email "sere.def@gmail.com"

What user name should I use?This doesn‚Äôt matter. Your commits will be labelled with this user name though, so make it informative to potential collaborators (and future you).


What email should I use?This must be the email associated with your GitHub account.


Wait, what happened?
git config --global --list



Check out the Software Carpentry for more things you can do with git config.


You can also set your Git user name and email from within R thanks to the usethis package.
# Install usethis (if needed)
# install.packages("usethis") # or pak::pak("usethis")

library(usethis) 
use_git_config(user.name = "Serena Defina", user.email = "sere.def@gmail.com")

I do quite a bit of R package dev, so I have library(usethis) in my .Rprofile file.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Can you hear me now?
So, you have Git working on your local machine (yey). Now it‚Äôs time to talk to GitHub.

Recall: GitHub is a remote Git server.
To interact with it, we have to make a request containing some credentials.
In English please: we need to prove that we are a specific GitHub user, who‚Äôs allowed to do whatever we‚Äôre asking to do.


There are two ways (or ‚Äúprotocols‚Äù) to communicate with a remote server, each using different credentials.

HTTPS: use a personal access token (PAT)
SSH: use SSH keys








HTTPS or SSH?


GitHub recommends HTTPS, presumably becasue it is easier to get working (especially for Windows users). Tech-y people will die on the SSH hill.
Anyway, don‚Äôt worry too much. This is not an all-or-nothing decision and it‚Äôs a relatively easy to revisit later.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: Set up personal access tokens (PAT) for HTTPS
text:
Set up personal access tokens (PAT) for HTTPS

In‚ÄÇROn GitHub


Remember usethis?
usethis::create_github_token()
Copy the generated PAT to your clipboard and use it every time a Git operation asks for your password (very confusing, I know)
‚Ä¶but best to store the PAT right now so you won‚Äôt loose it:
Back to R:
gitcreds::gitcreds_set() 
Paste the PAT in response to the dialogue in the console.
Done! Check your set-up with:
usethis::git_sitrep()


*Assuming you are signed in
Go to: https://github.com/settings/tokens

Click on your profile icon (top right corner) > Settings > Developer Settings (at end of the sidebar menu) > Personal access tokens > Tokens (classic)

Click on Generate new token > Generate new token (classic)
Select scopes: ‚Äúrepo‚Äù, ‚Äúuser‚Äù, and ‚Äúworkflow‚Äù (default from usethis)
Click on Generate token.
Copy the generated PAT to your clipboard.
Provide this PAT next time a Git operation asks for your password‚Ä¶ or store it in your favourite password manager.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Set up keys for SSH
Here is what is going to happen:

We‚Äôll generate a key pair (i.e.¬†two long strings of characters): one public and one private key.
We‚Äôll place the public key on a server (aka GitHub!),
We‚Äôll add the private key to our ssh-agent on the client (aka your computer!).
When the two match up, the system unlocks without the need for a password. Magic.








Some advice


[It‚Äôs normal to associate multiple public keys with your GitHub account. You should probably have one key pair per computer (at least, I do this).]{m-space}
You can increase security even more by protecting the private key with a passphrase. However, that requires some additional configuration (nothing mad, have a google at it)

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Step 1: generate SSH keys

From‚ÄÇRStudioFrom the shell


Go to Tools > Global Options‚Ä¶ > Git/SVN > Create SSH Key‚Ä¶
[RStudio will prompt you for a (optional) passphrase.]{m-up-space}
If you‚Äôre completely new at all this, skip the passphrase for now. You can implement it next time, when you are more comfortable with system configuration.
Click on Create
RStudio will generate and store the files ~/.ssh/id_ed25519 and ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub.







SSH keys file names


SSH key files follow the typical pattern id_<something>.pub (the public key) and id_<something> (the private key), where <something> reflects the key type.
rsa historically has been the most common. However, these days GitHub encourages users to generate SSH keys with the ed25519 algorithm instead (default option).






Create the key pair:
*a meaningful comment could be the name of your computer, for example
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "DESCRIPTIVE-COMMENT"
If your system is too old to support the ed25519 algorithm, substitute ‚Äúed25519‚Äù with ‚Äúrsa -b 4096‚Äù.
Accept the proposal to save the key in the default location (just press Enter)
You have the option to protect the key with a passphrase.
If you‚Äôre completely new at all this, skip the passphrase and implement it next time, when you are more comfortable with system configuration.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Step 2: the client
We need to tell your ssh-agent about the key.







Caution


Things get a little OS-specific around here. When in doubt, consult GitHub‚Äôs instructions for SSH, which is kept current and accounts for more unusual situations than I can.





On Linux or macOSOn Windows


Make sure ssh-agent is enabled:
eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"
You should see something like ‚ÄúAgent pid <some number>‚Äù.
If this fails, try again as superuser (sudo su > eval "$(ssh-agent -s)" > exit).
Add your key to the ssh agent:
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
If you set a passphrase, you‚Äôll be challenged for it here.


In the Git Bash shell, make sure ssh-agent is enabled:
eval $(ssh-agent -s)
You should see something like ‚ÄúAgent pid <some number>‚Äù.
Add your key to the ssh agent:
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Step 3: the server
The last thing we need to do is store a copy of your public key on GitHub.

Copy the public key onto your clipboard.


In‚ÄÇRStudioIn the shell


Go to Tools > Global Options‚Ä¶ > Git/SVN.
You should see something like ~/.ssh/id_ed25519 in the SSH Key box.
Click on View public key and copy that to your clipboard.


Open the ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub file (in whatever editor) and copy its content.
Some examples: pbcopy < ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pup (on macOS), xclip -sel clip < ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub (on Linux), clip < ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub (on Windows)



 2. Got to GitHub and register the public key

Click on your profile pic (upper right corner) > Settings > SSH and GPG keys > New SSH key. Paste your public key in the ‚ÄúKey‚Äù box. Give it an informative title (e.g.¬†the descriptive comment you used during key creation). Click ‚ÄúAdd SSH key‚Äù.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Done!
Thank god, you are now set-up and ready to use Git.
We all deserve a break.
But first, one last test for peace of mind:
ssh -T git@github.com

Questions?

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Let‚Äôs get down to it
Now that we are done setting up, it‚Äôs about damn time to see what was all that pain even for:

In this section, we‚Äôll go over four realistic workflows you may use in you daily Gitventures

New project - GitHub first: the easiest way to get a working project.
Existing project - GitHub first: a deeply pragmatic way to get pre-existing work onto GitHub.
Existing project - GitHub last: the ‚Äúproper‚Äù way to connect existing local work to GitHub, when there‚Äôs already a Git history.
Contributing to someone else‚Äôs work: your gateway drug to open-source heaven.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
(1) Create a repository
It‚Äôs (finally) time to make your first repository!

Go to GitHub and make sure you are logged in. Click on your profile pic (top-right corner) > Repositories > New

Fill some info in:

Repository name: approach this as you would a variable name: descriptive but brief, no spaces. Letters, digits, -, ., or _ are allowed. Description (for humans): It‚Äôs nice to have something here, so you‚Äôll see it appear in the README. e.g.¬†‚ÄúAnalysis of the stuff‚Äù. Visibility: Public or private (don‚Äôt sweat it, can always change it later) Add README: generally a good idea, this is the landing page for your repo Templates, .gitignore and licences we will talk about in a moment, ignore for now.

Click on Create repository

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: Clone your repo to your computer
text:
Clone your repo to your computer
Now, on the repo page, click the big green button that says <>‚ÄÇCode

Copy a clone URL to your clipboard.
Remember when we talked about HTTPS and SSH? Here they are again.
The type of URL you copy determines the protocol GitHub will use, so if you have PAT set up, copy the HTTPS URL, if you are using SSH keys, go for SSH.
Now, you have a few ways to get this onto your computer‚Ä¶

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: Clone your repo to your computer
text:
Clone your repo to your computer
Let‚Äôs use the URL we just copied from GitHub.

In the shellIn‚ÄÇRIn‚ÄÇRStudio



If your shell cooperates, you should be able to paste the whole https://... bit, but some shells are not (immediately) clipboard aware. In that sad case, you must type it (accurately), best of luck sailor!

This should look something like this:
git clone https://github.com/<YOUR-USERNAME>/<YOUR-REPOSITORY>.git







Where am I?


Take charge of ‚Äì or at least notice! ‚Äì what directory you‚Äôre in. pwd displays the working directory. cd is the command to change it.






Remember usethis?
usethis::create_from_github(
  "https://github.com/<YOUR-USERNAME>/<YOUR-REPOSITORY>.git",
  destdir = "~/path/to/where/you/want/the/local/repo/"
)
The first argument (repo_spec) accepts various forms of GitHub repo specifications (see the docs). We will use the URL we just copied from GitHub.
The destdir argument specifies the parent directory where you want the new folder (and local Git repo) to live. If you don‚Äôt specify it, usethis defaults to some very conspicuous place, like your Desktop.


Start a new Project:

File > New Project‚Ä¶ > Version Control > Git > In ‚ÄúRepository URL‚Äù, paste the URL of your new GitHub repo > Accept the default project directory name (i.e.¬†the GitHub repo name) > And pay attention to where the Project will be saved locally > Check ‚ÄúOpen in new session‚Äù (that‚Äôs what you usually want in real life) and click on Create Project








Troubles in paradise?


Do you NOT see an option to get the Project from Version Control? Restart RStudio and try again.Still no luck? Check out these troubleshooting tips.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: Exercise: make a repo and clone it
text:
Exercise: make a repo and clone it

Create a repository (get creative) and give it a README
Clone it on your laptop
Make this new repo your working directory, list its files, display the README
Bonus: what does git remote show origin tell you?

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: Make a local change and commit to it
text:
Make a local change and commit to it
Every time you finish a valuable chunk of work (probably a few times a day)

In the shellIn‚ÄÇRStudio


Make the repo your working directory
cd <YOUR-REPOSITORY>
Let‚Äôs make a small change:
echo "A line I wrote on my local computer " >> README.md
I am happy with this change, now let‚Äôs stage (‚Äúadd‚Äù) and commit to it
git add README.md
git commit -m "Look ma, a commit from my local computer"


Let‚Äôs make a small change: e.g., adding the line ‚ÄúThis is a line from RStudio‚Äù to the README.
Save your changes.
Open the Git tab in upper right pane (or wherever you have put your ‚ÄúEnvironment‚Äù pane, you eretic).
Check the ‚ÄúStaged‚Äù box for the files you want to commit and click (surprise) Commit
Type a message in ‚ÄúCommit message‚Äù, e.g.¬†‚ÄúCommit from RStudio‚Äù.
Click Commit.

Shall we tell GitHub about this?
Time to share (push) your changes with the world (or with GitHub anyway)

Now, this will seem counterintuitive, but first let‚Äôs stop and‚Ä¶ pull from GitHub.
I doubt anything will happen (i.e.¬†you‚Äôll get "Already up-to-date.") but this is a good habit to catch‚Ä¶ can you guess why?


In the shellIn‚ÄÇRStudio


(optional) get most recent version from GitHub:
git pull
Send your local changes to GitHub
git push

(optional) Click Pull to get most recent version from GitHub

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
(2) Exisiting project, GitHub first
What if you already have an existing project, somewhere in a directory on your computer?
If this is not (yet) a Git-tracked project, it should easy-easy

First create a new repository on GitHub (whithout a README if happen to already have one)
Clone it on you local computer
Bring your existing project over, using your favorite method of moving or copying files.
Check that your new files appear as new untracked files.
Stage, commit and‚Ä¶ wait








Don‚Äôt push any data, for the love of God


Take a moment to stop and think: this is about to leave your local computer and go to GitHub. Make sure you did not commit any data, passwords or anything else you don‚Äôt want to share with the world.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Say hi to .gitignore, everyone
You can absolutely keep a file locally in a repository, without ever committing it to the GitHub repo. Just let it sit there, without staging it. No harm done.
If this is a long-term situation, however, you may find it tidier to list the file in .gitignore. This is a special file that tells Git to just ignore things inside a local folder.

My .gitignore usuallly looks something like this:
.DS_Store # macOS

.Rhistory # for R projects # or __pycache__/ # for Python projects

data/ # All things data
*.csv
*.rds
*.RData
*.sav

Create a new repository for it on GitHub (you can use a Private one if you are feeling paranoid)

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Why GitHub first?
This is a somewhat technical but important point about Git.
There is a big advantage of the GitHub first, then RStudio/R workflow:

the remote GitHub repo is already configured as the origin remote for your local repo
your local main branch is now tracking the main on GitHub.

The practical implication is that you are already set up to push and pull. No need to fanny around setting up Git remotes and tracking branches in the shell.
Wait, what are you talking about?
Let‚Äôs a look at:
git remote show origin

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
(3) Existing project, GitHub last
If you have followed any other Git tutorial though, chances are that you started from:

In the shellCan be de done in‚ÄÇR‚ÄÇtoo, FYI


git init


usethis::use_git()



In this situation, you will have an existing project, that is already a Git repo (with a history you care about), but it does not have a remote GitHub repo yet.

This may be less ideal for a newbie, because there are more opportunities to get confused and make a mistake.
But it‚Äôs not the end of the world‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs tackle this.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: Create and connect a GitHub repo
text:
Create and connect a GitHub repo

In‚ÄÇRIn the shell


Yet again, usethis to the rescue

Note: you must have a personal access token (PAT) configured for this.

usethis::use_github()
What will happen:

Creates a new repo on GitHub.
Configures that new repo as the origin remote for the local repo.
Sets up your local default branch (e.g.¬†main) to track same brain on origin
Does an initial push
Opens the new repo in your browser



First, create a new repo on GitHub (you already know how), but:

give it the sane name of your local project‚Äôs directory
Do not initialize this repository with anything in it (no README)

Now, in the shell:
git remote add origin https://github.com/<YOUR-USERNAME>/<YOUR-REPOSITORY>.git
Push and cement the tracking relationship between your local main branch and main on GitHub (or whatever your default branch is)
git push --set-upstream origin main

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
(4) Contribute to someone else‚Äôs work
The open-source community is cozy, and you are always welcome üòÑ
POV: you want to get a copy of someone else‚Äôs repo (OWNER/REPO) and propose a change.

Here is what needs to happen:

fork the source repo (OWNER/REPO): i.e.¬†create a remote copy of the source repo on GitHub.
clone your fork (YOU/REPO) on your computer
(Optional, but recommended) Configure the source repo as the upstream remote
(Optional, but recommended) Configure your local main branch (or whatever the default is) to track upstream/main (instead of origin/main)
(Optional, but very recommended)Create a new branch where to make your changes
Send a pull request to OWNER, to propose your changes.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Fork, clone & configure (steps 1-4)

In‚ÄÇRIn the shell


usethis::create_from_github(
  "https://github.com/OWNER/REPO",
  destdir = "~/path/to/where/you/want/the/local/repo/",
  fork = TRUE
)
This will complete steps 1-4, putting you in perfect position to:
(a) sync up with ongoing developments in the source repo and
(b) propose new changes from your fork.
If you are using RStudio, it will also create and open an RStudio Project for you.
Let‚Äôs check what happened:
usethis::git_remotes()



Assuming you‚Äôre already on the source repo page: click on Fork (upper right corner) > accept the defaults > click on Create fork

This creates a copy of REPO under your GitHub account and takes you there in the browser.
Now clone YOU/REPO (you already know how).
Next, we need to make sure we stay current with developments in the source repo:

Configure the source repo as the upstream remote

Copy the URL of the source repo (OWNER/REPO).

It‚Äôs easy to get to from your fork (YOU/REPO), via the forked from link in the upper left.

Then:
git remote add upstream https://github.com/OWNER/REPO.git
Now that upstream is configured, especially if you configured it for the first time, do:
git fetch upstream
This should get you nicely up to date with all the remote info you need.
2. Configure your local main branch to track upstream/main.
Last thing:
git branch --set-upstream-to upstream/main
# git branch -u upstream/main # for lazy people
Ok, let‚Äôs check what happened:
git remote -v
Done! (finally)
If you found this kind of long and tedious, consider using usethis::create_from_github() next time‚Ä¶

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Create a new branch
When working on a fork, it is a good idea to never mess with the main branch.

In‚ÄÇRIn the shell


usethis::pr_init(branch = "BRANCH-NAME")
This will create a local branch called BRANCH-NAME and ‚Äúswitch to it‚Äù (or ‚Äúcheck it out‚Äù).


Create a new branch:
git branch BRANCH-NAME
Switch to the new branch:
git checkout BRANCH-NAME
Or you can use the shortcut git checkout -b BRANCH-NAME



Now, just make your changes and commit them as usual.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Submit a pull request
The last thing we need to do is let OWNER know about the chage we want to propose.

In‚ÄÇRIn the shell / GitHub


usethis::pr_push()
This pushes the local change to your copy of REPO on GitHub and opens a browser window.
All is left for you to do is click Create pull request to make the PR.
GitHub will ping OWNER for you, they will review our pull request and the rest is out of your hands.


Make sure you first push your changes to the remote, e.g.:
git push -u origin BRANCH-NAME.‚Äã
Then, go to the your fork‚Äôs page on GitHub and select the BRANCH-NAME.

You should see a yellow banner, with a Compare & pull request button, click on that > compare across forks > choose the ‚Äúbase branch‚Äù (this is the branch of the upstream repository you‚Äôd like to merge changes into, probably main)

Add a title and description and hit Create pull request

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: You are asking too many questions
text:
You are asking too many questions







‚ÄÇWhy you should never commit to main (on a fork)


When you do commit to main, it creates a divergence between that branch‚Äôs history in the source repo vs.¬†your repo. Nothing but pain will come from this.
Instead, treat main as read-only: it will make life much easier when you want to pull upstream work into your copy.
The OWNER of REPO will also be happier to receive your pull request from a non-main branch.











‚ÄÇWhy track upstream/main instead of origin/main


So that a simple git pull pulls from the source repo, not from your fork.
It also means a simple git push will (attempt to) push to the source repo, which will almost always be rejected since you probably do not have permission. This failure will alert you to the fact that you‚Äôre doing something questionable, while it‚Äôs still easy to back out.

section: Build an online presence: GitHub Pages
text:
Build an online presence: GitHub Pages
GitHub offers static website hosting directly from your repository via GitHub Pages. With very minimal set-up you get a website that:

is completely free (for public repositories).You can even use your own custom domain at no extra cost
is automatically deployed: just push your code and your site updates instantly
has built-in version control (Git history and rollback capability)


But‚Ä¶ what can I use it for?

Personal and/or lab website (e.g.¬†see mine)
A project website or documentation page (e.g.¬†see this R package)
Presetations or courses (like this one!)
A blog
(With a bit of extra work) an interactive dashboard

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: Build an online presence: just plain GitHub
text:
Build an online presence: just plain GitHub
Even without Pages, the browsability of GitHub makes your work accessible to people who care about your content but who don‚Äôt (yet) use Git themselves.
Here are some tips to make your repos look extra nice:

READMEs are quite powerful
You already know that GitHub renders README.md at the top-level of your repo (as a landing page). But did you know you can have multiple README.md files, for example, for any logical group of files or mini project-within-your-project (i.e.¬†a sub-directory in your repository). You can use the README.md to annotate these files, collect relevant links, etc.


Use tabular data
GitHub will nicely render tabular data in the form of .csv (comma-separated) and .tsv (tab-separated) files. Take advantage of this!


Images, HTML, Python/R notebooks‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs all fair game

text:
Run a course with GitHub
GitHub Organizations are excellent tools for interactive educational courses.
Check out this tutorial

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: Finding stuff: let me GitHub Search that for you
text:
Finding stuff: let me GitHub Search that for you
Did you ever find a function that seems useful has no examples? Or is poorly documented? Wouldn‚Äôt it be nice to find functioning instances of it ‚Äúin the wild‚Äù?
The GitHub Search box is just what the doctor ordered.

For example, wonder how packages on CRAN use the llply() function from plyr?
"llply" owner:cran language:R
GitHub Search has loads of useful setting and options.
Read about them here, here and here

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Finding stuff: the file finder


Whenever you are on a repo‚Äôs page, you can press t toactivate the file finder.
This is very helpful, especially when there are files tucked into lots of subdirectories.

You found it, don‚Äôt loose it
When you‚Äôre viewing a specific file, you can press y to get a permanent link to that specific file or specific line(s) inside that file.
What‚Äôs a permanent link?
Good question. This is a link that will not break, even when the file is deleted, renamed or if lines get inserted / deleted.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: Let people correct you on the internet
text:
Let people correct you on the internet
They love that!
Speaking of links, did you know that you can create a link that takes people directly to an editing interface in the browser.

Behind the scenes (assuming the click-er is signed into GitHub, and they are not you) this will create a fork in their account and send you a pull request for the changes.

An edit link would look something like this:
[Click here to edit!](<YOU REPO URL>/edit/main/<path to target source file>)

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Automate tasks: GitHub Actions
Automated (and reproducible!) workflows can be built directly into GitHub with Actions.

But‚Ä¶ what can I use it for?

Automatically re-run analyses (in a clean environment), for example, whenever code or data changes ‚Äì> freezing computations for reproducibility.
Automatically render manuscripts, presentations, and/or reports
Schedule workflows (regularly or with ‚Äúmanual: triggers), e.g.¬†

Search PubMed for new papers on a topic, every month
Whenever the code (or the data) is updated, run some validation checks / tests (a little something called continuous integration)




There is a whole marketplace of Actions out there.
Also check this tutorial for researchers.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
text:
Project management with GitHub Projects
GitHub provides built-in tools for planning, tracking, and coordinating work so you can manage entire projects alongside your code and writing.‚Äã
GitHub Projects sits on top of issues and pull requests as a flexible table, board, and roadmap that you can filter, sort, and group to match your workflow.‚Äã

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: Some extra tips for the way: cleaning up
text:
Some extra tips for the way: cleaning up
You can delete the ‚Äúlocal‚Äù repo whenever you like (it‚Äôs just a regular directory on your computer).
But, if you are doing it in the shell, use:
rm -rf <YOUR-REPOSITORY>
-rf will save you some time saying ‚Äúyes‚Äù delete this hidden git file a gazillion times
You also want to remove the remote repo?
In the browser, go to your repo‚Äôs landing page > Click on Settings > Scroll all the way down, click on delete repository and do as it asks.

title: Git & Github  for researchers
section: Some extra tips for the way: comparing versions
text:
Some extra tips for the way: comparing versions
RStudio will provide you with pretty ways to see the differences between versions.
In the shell, use:
git diff

text:
Conclusions and goodbyes
There you have it, you are now an honest GitHub citizen.
Now just ‚Äúlather, rinse, repeat‚Äù.
The tools and workflows we saw today are widely regarded as current best practice, yet, sadly, we generally neither practice nor preach it in academic settings.
‚Ä¶but that was until you came around!
Thanks for listening to me <3
See you on GitHub
